DT Article
TI First selenosteid placoderms from the eastern Anti-Atlas of Morocco;
   osteology, phylogeny and palaeogeographical implications.
AU Ruecklin, Martin (M.Ruecklin@bristol.ac.uk) 
SO Palaeontology (Oxford)
VL 54
IS 1
PS 25-62
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new placoderm assemblage is reported from the Kellwasser facies of the
   eastern Anti-Atlas, Morocco. This is the first record of an abundant
   Frasnian placoderm assemblage from Africa. The following new selenosteid
   taxa are described: Draconichthys elegans gen. et sp. nov., Enseosteus
   marocanensis sp. nov. and Walterosteus lelievrei sp. nov. In addition,
   material of Rhinosteus cf. parvulus is figured and described for the
   first time from Gondwana. The genera Enseosteus, Rhinosteus and
   Walterosteus are reviewed. 'Wildungenichthys' is regarded as a junior
   subjective synonym of Walterosteus. The new material and a revision of
   the taxa from Bad Wildungen, Germany, are the basis for a new
   phylogenetic analysis of the selenosteid arthrodires. The monophyly of
   the selenosteids is confirmed. The North American selenosteids are a
   sister group of Moroccan and European selenosteids, excluding
   Pachyosteus. The Moroccan vertebrate assemblage resembles that of Bad
   Wildungen. This supports the close palaeogeographical positions of
   Gondwana and Laurussia during the Late Devonian and indicates that
   biogeographical barriers for placoderms that could have separated the
   two assemblages were absent.

TI First beetle elytra, abdomen (Coleoptera) and a mine trace from Lunz
   (Carnian, Late Triassic, Lunz-am-See, Austria) and their taphonomical
   and evolutionary aspects.
AU Meller, Barbara (barbara.meller@univie.ac.at) 
   Ponomarenko, Alexander G.
   Vasilenko, Dmitry V.
   Fischer, Thilo C.
   Aschauer, Birgitt
SO Palaeontology (Oxford)
VL 54
IS 1
PS 97-110
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 2
U2 18
AB Four new species of Permosynidae are described: Platycrossus caroli
   Ponomarenko in Meller et al. sp. nov., Hydrobiites handlirschi
   Ponomarenko in Meller et al. sp. nov., Ademosyne polyzetete Ponomarenko
   in Meller et al. sp. nov. and Diarcuipenna bennettitophila Ponomarenko
   in Meller et al. sp. nov. Together with one polyphagous abdomen, they
   represent the first beetle remains from the Lunz formation, known for
   its richness in bennettite and cycad leaf remains and also for the
   bennettite reproductive organs. Furthermore, the first insect mine trace
   on a Nilssonia leaf segment is described, which is one of the most
   ancient linear mine traces. The rareness of insect remains in the
   plant-bearing layers of the Lunz formation is still an enigma from the
   taphonomical-chemical point of view. The palaeoentomological and
   palaeobotanical considerations tentatively indicate a relationship
   between the rare occurrence of coniferous plants and the evolution or
   radiation of phytophagous insects during this time.

DT Article
TI Gilianelles: Late Cretaceous microproblematica from Europe and Central
   America.
AU Odin, Gilles Serge (gilles.odin@upmc.fr) 
SO Palaeontology (Oxford)
VL 54
IS 1
PS 133-144
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB During the last two decades, a range of microfossils have been collected
   from strata of Late Cretaceous (Coniacian-Maastrichtian) age. The name
   gilianelles has been coined to accommodate these microproblematica. On
   the basis of many thousands of specimens, typical features of this group
   have now been assessed. Distinctive traits are calcareous unilocular,
   basically axially symmetrical test, in the size range 80-200 [mu]m, with
   a single-layered wall of radially arranged crystals, 15 [mu]m thick, the
   outer surface with a crochet-like nanostructure, a small-sized aperture
   (one tenth of test diameter), situated on the upper surface in vivo.
   Secondary criteria include modification of axial test symmetry into
   radial or bilateral symmetry, development of expansions, either spiny or
   laminar and presence of longitudinal and latitudinal ornament. To date,
   60 taxa have been described from northern Spain to northern Germany and
   from Central America. Evolutionary patterns of gilianelles are diverse,
   with both short- and long-ranging forms, some of which comprise lineages
   that were affected by a marked crisis dated at about 73 Ma. This event
   is here illustrated by the tribe Coraliellini, of which a key taxon,
   Coraliella cognatio, is described as new. Previous interpretations of
   Gilianelles as dinoflagellate cysts are discussed and rejected.
C1 Odin, Gilles Serge; Univ Paris 06, Dept Geol Sedimentaire, 4 Pl Jussieu,
   Case 119, F-75252 Paris 05, France, France.
EM gilles.odin@upmc.fr
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology; Evolutionary Biology; Environmental
   Sciences &Ecology
SN 0031-0239
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Skeletal and supporting structures;
   Evolution; Ecology; Land zones; Neotropical region; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Central America; West Indies; Geological time periods;
   Mesozoic
DE Coraliella cognatio [France /  / new species] [Cretaceous /  / ]. 
   Gilianelles [Test / Test characteristics / systematics] [Evolution /
   Evolutionary patterns / ] [Ecology / Palaeoenvironment / ] [Europe /  /
   distribution; stratigraphical distribution] [Cuba /  / ] [Cretaceous /
   Upper Cretaceous / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda
OR Coraliella cognatio (Rhizopoda): [Sp nov, France, Cretaceous, P. 136;
   Fossil]. 
   Gilianelles (Rhizopoda): [Fossil].

UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14705036032

PT J
AN ZOOR14705036033
DT Article
TI Morphology and systematics of Anthracomartidae (Arachnida:
   Trigonotarbida).
AU Garwood, Russell J. (russell.garwood03@imperial.ac.uk) 
   Dunlop, Jason A.
SO Palaeontology (Oxford)
VL 54
IS 1
PS 145-161
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 12
AB X-ray microtomography (XMT) was applied to three species of the extinct
   arachnid order Trigonotarbida, hosted in siderite nodules from the late
   Carboniferous British Middle Coal Measures. All three, Cryptomartus
   Hindi (Pocock, 1911), Cleptomartus plautus (Petrunkevitch, 1949) and
   Maiocercus celticus (Pocock, 1902), belong to the family
   Anthracomartidae. As well as providing interactive three-dimensional
   visualisations of their likely appearance in life, XMT study has
   resolved new morphological detail, yielding key data about the likely
   stance and habitus of these early arachnids. Similarities in the form of
   the carapace, eyes and coxosternal region between anthracomartids and
   the Devonian genus Palaeocharinus Hirst, 1923 are highlighted. Analogies
   in limb disposition are drawn between anthracomartids and modern crab
   spiders (Araneae: Thomisidae), which exhibit sit-and-wait style
   predatory behaviour. Anthracomartids are relatively common fossils at
   many Coal Measures localities. Although they appear to exhibit limited
   morphological variation, numerous genera and species have been proposed
   in the literature, often distinguished from each other on rather trivial
   characters. From our reconstruction of well-preserved examples, we have
   resolved a number of common features likely to be present in a typical
   anthracomartid. Comparisons to this model suggest that the characters on
   which many anthracomartid genera are distinguished may be artefacts of
   preservation. We hence treat Promygale Fric, 1901, Brachylycosa Fric,
   1904, Perneria Fric, 1904, Coryphomartus link Petrunkevitch, 1945,
   Cryptomartus Petrunkevitch, 1945, Pleomartus Petrunkevitch, 1945,
   Cleptomartus Petrunkevitch, 1949 and Oomartus Petrunkevitch, 1953 as
   junior synonyms of the type genus of the family, Anthracomartus Karsch,
   1882. Only the genera Brachypyge Woodward, 1878 and Maiocercus Pocock,
   1911 are additionally retained. Within Anthracomartus, Cleptomartus
   planus Petrunkevitch, 1949, Cryptomartus meyeri link Guthorl, 1964,
   Cleptomartus hangardi Guthorl, 1965 and Cryptomartus rebskei Brauckmann,
   1984 are treated as junior synonyms of A. Hindi Pocock, 1911 (all syn.
   nov.). Cleptomartus plautus Petrunkevitch, 1949 and Anthracomartus
   denuiti Pruvost, 1922 are treated as junior synonyms of A. priesti
   Pocock, 1911 (both syn. nov.).
C1 Garwood, Russell J.; Univ London Imperial Coll Sci Technol and Med, Dept
   Earth Sci and Engn, London SW7 2AZ, United Kingdom, United Kingdom.
EM russell.garwood03@imperial.ac.uk
RI Dunlop, Jason A./AAC-8042-2019
OI Garwood, Russell/0000-0002-2803-9471
SC Zoology; Anatomy &Morphology
SN 0031-0239
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; Diagnosis; Combination; Synonymy; Taxonomy;
   Taxonomic position; General morphology; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; United Kingdom; Geological time periods; Palaeozoic
DE Anthracomartidae [General morphology /  / X-ray microtomography;
   systematics] [Carboniferous / Upper Carboniferous / ]. 
   Anthracomartus hindi; Cleptomartus plautus; Maiocercus celticus [General
   morphology /  / X-ray microtomography; systematics] [England /  / ]
   [Carboniferous / Upper Carboniferous / ]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

DT Article
TI Late Devonian rhynchonellids (Brachiopoda) from the Junggar Basin,
   northwestern Xinjiang.
AU Chen, Xiu-Qin (xqchen@nigpas.ac.cn) 
   Yang, Zhen
SO Palaeoworld
VL 20
IS 1
PS 46-60
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Rhynchonellid brachiopods from the Late Devonian (broadly late
   Frasnian[long dash]Famennian) Hongguleleng Formation in the Junggar
   Basin, northwestern Xinjiang, consist of 12 species (six not identified
   to species-level) in 11 genera. Three new species are established with
   the aid of serial sections: Sinotectirostrum triangularum,
   Evanescirostrum gracilis and Megalopterorhynchus boulongourensis. Some
   previously reported taxa are revised.
C1 Chen, Xiu-Qin; Nanjing Institute of Geology and Palaeontology, Chinese
   Academy of Sciences, Nanjing 210008, China, China.
EM xqchen@nigpas.ac.cn

   [Devonian /  / ].

   / Late Devonian / ].

   (Coleoptera, Staphylinidae, Pselaphinae) from China. V. Sinoclavigerodes
   yalianae gen. et sp. nov. (Clavigeritae) Associated with Anoplolepis
   gracilipes (Formicidae).
AU Yin, Zi-Wei
   Hlavac, Peter
   Zhao, Mei-Jun (meijunzhao@shnu.edu.cn) 
SO Sociobiology
VL 57
IS 1
PS 1-9
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB A new genus and species, Sinoclavigerodes yalianae, of myrmecophilous
   supertribe Clavigeritae is described and illustrated, revealing the
   third genus of the supertribe discovered in China. The new species was
   collected in association with the ant Anoplolepis gracilipes. Systematic
   positions of the new taxa are discussed.

DT Article
TI A New Species of the Genus Tetramorium (Hymenoptera: Formicidae) From
   Chamela, Jalisco, Mexico.
AU Marques, T. (tatiannemarques@yahoo.com.br) 
   Vasquez-Bolanos, M.
   Quesada, M.
SO Sociobiology
VL 57
IS 1
PS 115-122
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB A new ant species of the genus Tetramorium from Chamela, Jalisco, Mexico
   is described. It is in the tortuosum group and differs from any other
   species (T. bicolorum Vasquez-Bolanos 2007; T. hispidum (Wheeler 1915);
   77 mexicanum Bolton 1979; T. placidum Bolton 1979 and 7: spinosum
   (Pergande 1896)) as it has the smallest: head width, from 0.58 to 0.68
   mm and a maximum total length of 2.8 mm. This species is distinguished
   from T placidum by the rugolose dorsal surface of the petiole and the
   sparse pilosity on the dorsal surface of the alitrunk. The type locality
   and the known distribution is Tropical Dry Forest at an altitude of 180
   meters above sea level. Only workers from this species were examined.
C1 Marques, T.; Univ Fed Vicosa, Dept Biol Anim, BR-36570000 Vicosa, MG,
   Brazil, Brazil.
EM tatiannemarques@yahoo.com.br
OI Quesada, Mauricio/0000-0002-7776-9286
SC Zoology
SN 0361-6525
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Nearctic region; North
   America
DE Tetramorium azcatltontlium [Mexico /  / New species]. 
TN Arthropods; Hymenopterans; Insects; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Insecta, Hymenoptera, Apocrita, Aculeata,
   Formicoidea, Formicidae
OR Tetramorium azcatltontlium (Formicidae): [Sp nov, Mexico, P. 118].

PT J
AN ZOOR14704032999
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI EARLY JURASSIC OVIPOSITORIES ON BENNETTITALEAN LEAVES FROM ROMANIA.
AU Popa, Mihae E. (mihai@mepopa.com) 
   Zaharia, Andreea
SO Acta Palaeontologica Romaniae
VL 7
PS 285-290
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB Early Jurassic (Hettangian[long dash]Sinemurian) rare insect
   ovipositories occurring on Pterophyllum sp. bennettitalean
   (cycadeoidalean) leaves are described from Pregheda, a former open cast
   mine for bituminous coals belonging to the Sirinia Basin, Danubian Units
   of the South Carpathians, Romania. These ovipositories are represented
   by groups of 2-3 elliptical bodies, distributed with their longer axis
   parallel to the leaf venation, and associated in four distinct rows,
   parallel to the rachis, two rows on each side of it, a peculiar pattern
   for the ichnospecies Paleoovoides rectus (Vasilenko) Sarzetti et al.
   2009 to which the material is assigned. The Hettangian[long
   dash]Sinemurian ovipositories recorded in Pregheda belong to fossil
   representatives of the Order Odonata, such as fossil dragonflies or
   damselflies. They were generated after the leaf's abscission, in a
   wetland area associated with a coal-generating marsh.
C1 Popa, Mihae E.; Univ Bucharest, Fac Geol and Geophys, 1 Nicolae Balcescu
   Ave, Bucharest 010041, Romania, Romania.
EM mihai@mepopa.com
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Paleontology
SN 1842-371X
BD Reproduction; Reproductive behaviour; Ecology; Land zones; Palaearctic
   region; Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Odonata [Breeding site / Oviposition site / Ovipository traces on plant
   leaf Paleoovoidus rectus] [Egg laying /  / ] [Fossil traces /
   Ovipository traces on plant leaf / Paleoovoidus rectus] [Romania /  / ]
   [Jurassic / Early Jurassic / ]. 
   Paleoovoidus rectus [Fossil traces / Ovipository traces on plant leaf /
   Attributed to Odonata (Insecta); new record] [Romania /  / ovipository
   traces on plant leaf attributed to Odonata (Insecta)] [Jurassic / Early
   Jurassic / ]. 
TN Arthropods; Insects; Invertebrates

   Odonata (Insecta): [Fossil].

PT J
AN ZOOR14704033000
DT Article; Meeting paper
TI MIDDLE MIOCENE GLOBIGERINAS OF ROMANIA.
AU Popescu, Gheorghe
   Crihan, Ileana-Monica
SO Acta Palaeontologica Romaniae
VL 7
PS 291-313
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB The paper is an attempt to draw up an inventory of the planktonic
   foraminifera from the marine Middle Miocene of Romania. The studied
   geological sections are situated in the Neogene basins from the eastern
   border of the Pannonian Depression (e.g. Caransebes, Bega, and Zarand
   Basins), in Transylvania and connected basins (e.g. Ha[Thorn]eg Basin),
   in the strongly-deformed deposits from the Subcarpathians, and from the
   Getic Depression. 45 species belonging to 13 genera of planktonic
   foraminifera were described, of which one new genus (Globospina) and a
   new species (Globospina banatica). The descriptions are accompanied by
   remarks on the stratigraphic range, many times different from their
   range in the open seas.
C1 Popescu, Gheorghe; Str. Arh. Petre Antonescu nr. 4, bl. 29, apt. 14,
   sector 3, 023591 Bucharest, Romania, Romania.
SC Zoology; Paleontology
SN 1842-371X
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Land zones; Palaearctic region;
   Eurasia; Europe; Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Globigerinacea; Globorotaliacea [Romania /  / systematics; records]
   [Miocene / Middle Miocene / ]. 
   Globospina [Miocene /  / New genus]. 
   Globospina banatica [Romania /  / new species] [Miocene /  / ]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Sarcomastigophora, Sarcodina, Rhizopoda, Granuloreticulosea,
   Foraminiferida
OR Globigerinacea (Foraminiferida): [Fossil]. 
   Globorotaliacea (Foraminiferida): [Fossil]. 
   Globospina (Foraminiferida): [Gen nov, Of subfamily Globigerininae, Type
   species Globospina banatica, p. 296, Miocene; Fossil]. 
   Globospina banatica (Foraminiferida): [Sp nov, Romania, Miocene, P. 296;
   Fossil].

DT Article
TI Review of the mortality causes of Neotropical primates (Primates:
   Platyrrhini) at the Quinzinho de Barros Municipal Zoological Park
   (Sorocaba, Brazil), 1996-2006.
FT Revisao das causas de mortalidade de pimatas neotropicais (Primates:
   Platyrrhini) no Partque Zoologico Municipal Quinzinho de barros
   (Sorocaba, SP), 1996-2006.
AU Thijl Vanstreels, Ralph Eric
   Friceiello Teixeira, Rodrigo Hidalgo
   Camargo, Luis Carlos
   Veloso Nunes, Adauto Luis
   Rassy Braga, Fabricio
   Nali, Camila
   Reiko Matushima, Eliana
SO Clinica Veterinaria (Sao Paulo)
VL 16
IS 90
PS 46-52
PD janeiro-fevereiro 2011
PY 2011
LA Portuguese
U1 0
U2 0
AB Neotropical primates (Primates: Platyrrhini) are physiologically and
   clinically distinct from the primate species from other regions of the
   World, and thus require special attention in their captive husbandry and
   management. Clinical and necroscopical records from 1996 to 2006 of the
   Brazilian primates collection at Parque Zoologico Municipal Quinzinho de
   Barros (Sorocaba, SP, Brazil) were examined. The Brazilian primates
   collection that was studied in this project was predominantly composed
   of species with small body size (average body weight was 1.35 [plus or
   minus] 2.02kg, n = 220), a common tendency among Brazilian zoos. Major
   causes of death (n = 153) were viral/microbial infections (45%), traumas
   (18%), cachexia (7%), maternal abandonment (5%), and excessive
   parasitism (4%). This article discusses husbandry and preventive
   medicine strategies that may help reduce these causes of death.
SC Education &Educational Research; Zoology; Parasitology; Pathology;
   Environmental Sciences &Ecology
SN 1413-571X
BD Animals and man; Education and entertainment; Techniques; Parasites
   diseases and disorders; Ecology; Population dynamics; Land zones;
   Neotropical region; South America
DE Platyrrhini [Zoos and wildlife parks / Parque Zoologico Municipal
   Quinzinho de Barros / pathology; review; Neotropical taxa] [Care in
   captivity / Husbandry & preventive medicine strategies / ] [Parasites
   diseases and disorders /  / ] [Mortality / Mortalilty causes / ] [Brazil
   / Sao Paulo, Sorocaba / ]. 
TN Chordates; Mammals; Primates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Mammalia, Primates
OR Platyrrhini (Primates). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704033347
DA 2020-09-17
ER

AN ZOOR14704032871
DT Article
TI Euleiognathus, a new genus proposed for the Miocene ponyfish,
   Leiognathus tottori Yabumoto and Uyeno 1994 (Perciformes: Leiognathidae)
   from Japan.
AU Yabumoto, Yoshitaka (yabumoto@kmnh.jp) 
   Uyeno, Teruya
SO Ichthyological Research
VL 58
IS 1
PS 19-23
PD Jan 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new leiognathid genus Euleiognathus is proposed for Leiognathus
   tottori Yabumoto and Uyeno 1994, described from the Middle Miocene Iwami
   Formation of the Tottori Group, Tottori Prefecture, Japan. Euleiognathus
   differs from other genera of the family Leiognathidae in having
   serrations on the anterior edges of the second to fourth spines of the
   dorsal fin and relatively large uniserial conical teeth of the
   premaxilla.
C1 Yabumoto, Yoshitaka; Kitakyushu Museum Nat Hist & Human Hist,
   Yahatahigashi Ku, 2-4-1 Higashida, Fukuoka, Japan, Japan.
EM yabumoto@kmnh.jp

SN 1341-8998

   Geological time periods; Caenozoic; Tertiary; Neogene
DE Euleiognathus [Miocene /  / New genus]. 
TN Chordates; Fish; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Pisces, Osteichthyes, Actinopterygii,
   Perciformes, Leiognathidae
OR Euleiognathus (Leiognathidae): [Gen nov, Type species Leiognathus
   tottori Yabumoto & Uyeno 1994, p. 19, Miocene; Fossil].

   nov, Transferred from Leiognathus, p. 19; Fossil].

DT Article
TI Breeding biology of the Grey-headed Bulbul Pycnonotus priocephalus
   (Aves: Pycnonotidae) in the Western Ghats, India.
AU Balakrishnan, Peroth (baluperth@gmail.com) 
SO Journal of Threatened Taxa
VL 3
IS 1
PS 1415-1424
PD January 2011
PY 2011
UR http://threatenedtaxa.org
AW http://threatenedtaxa.org/ZooPrintJournal/2011/January/o238126i111415-14
   24.pdf
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB The breeding biology of the endemic Grey-headed Bulbul Pycnonotus
   priocephalus was studied from 2003 to 2005 in Silent Valley National
   Park, Western Ghats, India. Nests were located during three field
   seasons from the arrival (December) to the dispersal of the birds (June)
   and collected data on various breeding parameters, availability of
   fruits and weather conditions. All nests were found in mid-elevation
   evergreen forests ranging from 900 to 1,400 m elevation. Breeding
   occurred in the drier months (January[long dash]May), which coincides
   with high fruit availability. Nest building lasted 3[long dash]8 days.
   Majority of the nests (>72%; n = 39) were built on two plant species
   (Ochlandra travancorica and saplings of Syzygium sp.) and the mean nest
   height was 1.52 [plus or minus] 0.80 m (n = 52). Nests were randomly
   oriented around the nesting plants with a mean vector of orientation
   equaling 160.450. The clutch size averaged 1.53 [plus or minus] 0.50
   eggs (range = 1[long dash]2; n = 47). Incubation and nestling periods
   were 13 [plus or minus] 0.87 (n = 9) and 12 [plus or minus] 0.50 (n = 9)
   days, respectively. Overall nest success was 10.79%. Nest success rates
   varied among incubation and nestling periods. Grey-headed Bulbul exhibit
   life-history traits associated with low productivity such as short
   breeding season, low clutch size, fewer broods per year and high
   predation rates indicating that deterioration of breeding habitats might
   seriously hamper the long-term survival of the species.
C1 Balakrishnan, Peroth; Division of Conservation Ecology, Salim Ali Centre
   for Ornithology and Natural History, Anaikatty, Coimbatore, Tamil Nadu
   641108, India, India.
EM baluperth@gmail.com
SC Zoology; Reproductive Biology; Forestry
SN 0974-7893; 0974-7907
BD Reproduction; Habitat; Terrestrial habitat; Land zones; Oriental region;
   Eurasia; Asia
DE Pycnonotus priocephalus [Reproduction /  / ] [Forest and woodland /
   Forest / ] [India / Western Ghats, Silent Valley National Park / ]. 
TN Birds; Chordates; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Aves, Passeriformes, Pycnonotidae
OR Pycnonotus priocephalus (Pycnonotidae). 
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14704031141
OA DOAJ Gold

AN ZOOR14704030536
DT Article
TI A new basal ornithopod dinosaur from the Upper Cretaceous of South
   Korea.
AU Huh, Min
   Lee, Dae-Gil
   Kim, Jung-Kyun
   Lim, Jong-Deock
   Godefroit, Pascal (Pascal.Godefroit@naturalsciences.be) 
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 259
IS 1
PS 1-24
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 5
AB The Seonso Conglomerate (?Santonian - Campanian, Late Cretacous) of
   Boseong site 5 (southern coast of Korean Peninsula) has yielded
   well-preserved postcranial material belonging to a new taxon of
   ornithischian dinosaur, Koreanosaurus boseongensis nov. gen., nov. sp.
   This dinosaur is characterized by elongated neck vertebrae, very long
   and massive scapulocoracoid and humerus, proportionally short hindlimbs
   with a low hindlimb ratio for tibia/femur, and
   anteroposteriorly-elongated femoral head forming an obtuse 135[degree]
   angle with the femoral shaft. Koreano saurus displays a series of
   neornithischian synapomorphies. Amongst Neornithischia, most features of
   the postcranial skeleton suggest affinities with basal ornithopods and,
   amongst them, particularly with a small clade formed by three genera
   from the Cretaceous of Montana: Zephyrosaurus schaffi, Orodromeus
   makelai, and Oryctodromeus cubicularis. According to the morphological,
   phylogenetic, sedimentological, and taphonomic data at hand, it is
   tentatively postulated that Koreanosaurus was a burrowing dinosaur, like
   Oryctodromeus.
C1 Godefroit, Pascal; Royal Belgian Institute of Natural Sciences,
   Department of Palaeontology, rue Vautier 20, 1000 Brussels, Belgium,
   Belgium.
EM Pascal.Godefroit@naturalsciences.be
SC Zoology
SN 0077-7749

   Eurasia; Asia; Geological time periods; Mesozoic
DE Koreanosaurus [Cretaceous /  / New genus]. 
   Koreanosaurus boseongensis [South Korea /  / new species] [Cretaceous / 
   / ]. 
TN Chordates; Reptiles; Vertebrates
ST Animalia, Chordata, Vertebrata, Reptilia, Archosauria, Ornithischia,
   Ornithopoda
OR Koreanosaurus (Ornithopoda): [Gen nov, Type species Koreanosaurus
   boseongensis, p. 3, Cretaceous; Fossil]. 
   Koreanosaurus boseongensis (Ornithopoda): [Sp nov, South Korea,
   Cretaceous, P. 4; Fossil].

TI Sinemurian ammonites from Male Karpaty Mts., Western Carpathians,
   Slovakia. Part 1: Phylloceratoidea, Lytoceratoidea, Schlotheimiidae.
AU Meister, Christian (christian.meister@ville-ge.ch) 
   Schloegl, Jan
   Rakus, Milos
SO Neues Jahrbuch fuer Geologie und Palaeontologie Abhandlungen
VL 259
IS 1
PS 25-88
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Among the rich ammonite fauna of the condensed section of Chtelnica
   (Western Carpathians) 33 species are discussed for the Phylloceratoidea
   (Phylloceratidae (5), Juraphyllitidae (5)), Lytoceratoidea
   (Pleuroacanthidae (6), Lytoceratidae (4)) and Schlotheimiidae (13). Five
   species are new: Lytotropites compressus, Lytoceras perplexum,
   Angulaticeras (Sulciferites) helvii, Angulaticeras (Sulciferites)
   chtelnicaense, and Angulaticeras (Angulaticeras) spinosus n. sp. The
   latter is a key taxon to the understanding of the origin of the
   Phricodoceratidae. The age of the fauna covers a large period in the
   Sinemurian from the Bucklandi Zone up to the Turneri and/or partim
   Obtusum Zones.

   Palaeontology Department, 1 route de Malagnou, CP. 6434, CH-1211 Geneva
   6, Switzerland, Switzerland.

DT Article
TI [The tortricid fauna of Tunisia (Tortricidae).]
FT Zur Wicklerfauna Tunesiens (Tortricidae).
AU Blackstein, Hans (Hans.Blackstein@gmx.de) 
   Karisch, Timm
SO Nota Lepidopterologica
VL 33
IS 2
PS 219-229
PD 2010(2011)
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 0
AB The authors present new records of Tortricidae from the poorly known
   fauna of Tunisia. 23 species were captured during several expeditions
   between 2005 and 2008 by the German collectors H. Hoppe, T. Lange, L.
   Lehmann and A. Rudolph. The male and female genitalia of Cnephasia cf.
   albatana (Chretien, 1915) and the female genitalia of the holotype of
   Eana antiphila Meyrick, 1913 are figured for the first time. Aethes
   hoppei sp. n. is described as new species and belongs to the Aethes
   bilbaensis (Rossler, 1877) species group.
C1 Blackstein, Hans; Buckower Weg 1, 14712 Rathenow, Germany, Germany.
EM Hans.Blackstein@gmx.de

TI Contribution to the knowledge of the genus Zygaena Fabricius, 1775, in
   Iran (Zygaenidae). Part IX: On two newly discovered Mesembrynus taxa
   from the central and southern Zagros range.
AU Hofmann, Axel (hofmann@abl-freiburg.de) 
   Keil, Thomas
SO Nota Lepidopterologica
VL 33
IS 2
PS 233-248
PD 2010(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Two new taxa of the genus Zygaena are described from the Iranian Zagros
   range: Zvgaena mirzavansi sp. n. from the central part of the Zagros and
   Z. fredi valii ssp. n. from the mountainous regions in the province
   Kerman. There are observations on the preimaginal biology of the two
   taxa. For Z. mirzayansi sp. n., the full grown larva is known. It was
   found on Eryngium billardieri. Zygaena fredi valli ssp. n. feeds on
   Bupleurum exaltatum (M. Bieb.) or a very close related Bupleurum. The
   larvae of Z. fredi syntopica, Z. fredi escaleraiana and Z. mirzayansii
   are figured for the first time. The type-localities of Z. fredi
   escaleraiana and Z. escalerai have been located more precisely. The
   types of Z. fredi, Z. fredi escaleraiana, Z. fredi syntopica and Z.
   mirzayansi are figured.
C1 Hofmann, Axel; Verenenweg 4, 79206 Breisach-Hochstetten, Germany,

TI Teleiopsis laetitiae sp. n. and Teleiopsis lindae sp. n., two hitherto
   overlooked mountainous European species (Gelechiidae: Teleiodini).
AU Schmid, Juerg (schmid.ilanz@kns.ch) 
SO Nota Lepidopterologica
VL 33
IS 2
PS 271-283
PD 2010(2011)
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Teleiopsis laetitiae sp. n. is described based on nine males and two
   females collected in the Alps of Grisons, Switzerland. Wing pattern and
   genital characteristics are described and illustrated. Further specimens
   originating from Austria, Italy, Macedonia, Greece and Turkey were
   identified in museum collections. Teleiopsis lindae sp. n. is described
   and characterized based on specimens collected in Spain and Portugal.
   Differential diagnosis is provided for these and related species.

TI Tow [Two] new genus of Calliphoridae (Diptera: Calliphoridae).
AU Xue, Wan-qi
   Fei, Xu-dong
SO Shenyang Shifan Daxue Xuebao Ziran Kexue Ban
VL 29
IS 1
SU Sum 91
PS 1-5
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA Chinese
U1 0
U2 0
AB At present, world Calliphoridae classification system has been greatly
   changed. Originally, Calliphoridae of world was divided into 12
   subfamilies: Ameniinae, Bengalinae, Calliphorinae, Chrysomyinae,
   Helicoboscinae, Melanomyinae, Mesembrinellinae, Luciliinae, Phumosiinae,
   Polleniinae, Rhiniinae and Toxotarsinae; Calliphoridae of China was
   divided into 5 subfamilies: Ameniinae, Bengalinae, Calliphorinae,
   Phormiinae and Rhiniinae. Now, Bengalinae and Rhiniinae subfamilies have
   rised to Bengalidae and Rhiniidae respectively. Two new genus are
   established in this paper, they belong to Calliphorinae, viz.
   Sinotibetomyia Xue gen. nov. belong to Polleniini and type species is
   Sinotibetomyia curvifemura Xue et Fei, sp. nov., while Ypogymnadichosia
   Xue, gen. nov. belong to Melanomyini and type species is
   Ypogymnadichosia Yunnanensis Xue et Fei, sp. nov.. The type specimens
   are deposited in the Institute of Entomology, Shenyang Normal
   University, China.
C1 Xue, Wan-qi; Institute of Entomology, Shenyang Normal University,
   Shenyang 110034, China, China.

   Melanomyini, Type species Ypogymnadichosia yunnanensis, p. 3]. 
   Ypogymnadichosia yunnanensis (Calliphoridae): [Sp nov, China, P. 3].

DT Article
TI A new genus of cave-dwelling microcrustaceans from the Dinaric Region
   (south-east Europe): adaptations of true stygobitic Cladocera
   (Crustacea: Branchiopoda).
AU Van Damme, Kay (kay.vandamme@ugent.be) 
   Sinev, Artem Y.
SO Zoological Journal of the Linnean Society
VL 161
IS 1
PS 31-52
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB We revise 'true' stygobitic cladocerans and lift three species from
   Alona Baird, 1843 (Cladocera: Chydoridae). Species of Brancelia gen.
   nov. are inhabitants of saturated karst, collected in pools of residual
   water in the amphibious zones of a few caves in the Dinaric Region,
   Europe. All species are blind (regression of eye and ocellus), have
   elongated sensorial equipment (aesthetascs) and a short rostrum, reduced
   antennal spines, and a globular body. In contrast to earlier hypotheses,
   there is no epigean chydorid taxon from the Palaearctic that can be
   linked to Brancelia gen. nov. The new genus may be an offshoot of
   six-limbed Aloninae, but a littoral-benthic ancestor is not apparent and
   most likely extinct. Evolution of Brancelia gen. nov. parallels that of
   other subterranean Cladocera like Phreatalona Van Damme, Brancelj &
   Dumont, 2009. We discuss the functional morphology of Brancelia gen.
   nov. and compare its adaptations to a subterranean life mode with those
   of Phreatalona.
C1 Van Damme, Kay; State Univ Ghent, Dept Biol, KL Ledeganckstr 35, B-9000
   Ghent, Belgium, Belgium.
EM kay.vandamme@ugent.be
RI Van Damme, Kay/R-9983-2019; Sinev, Artem Y./J-8201-2012

DT Article
TI Two new Encarsia species (Hymenoptera: Aphelinidae) reared from eggs of
   Cicadellidae (Hemiptera: Auchenorrhyncha) in Argentina: an unusual new
   host association.
AU Polaszek, Andrew (ap@nhm.ac.uk) 
   Luft Albarracin, Erica
SO Journal of Natural History
VL 45
IS 1-2
PS 55-64
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 2
U2 5
AB Males of two undescribed Encarsia species were reared from eggs of two
   cicadellid species during a study of egg parasitoids of corn leafhopper,
   Dalbulus maidis (DeLong and Wolcott) in northwestern Argentina. Samples
   were collected during the summer of 2004-2007 using sentinel eggs, and
   several males of a new species of Encarsia (Hymenoptera: Chalcidoidea:
   Aphelinidae) were obtained. A single male of a closely related Encarsia
   species, also previously undescribed, was reared from an egg of another
   cicadellid on maize, Plesiommata mollicella (Fowler). These are the
   first records of any Encarsia species reared from eggs of Cicadellidae.
   The two new species are described as Encarsia dalbulae Polaszek and Luft
   Albarracin sp. nov., and Encarsia mollicellae Polaszek and Luft
   Albarracin sp. nov.
C1 Polaszek, Andrew; Nat Hist Museum, Dept Entomol, Cromwell Rd, London,
   United Kingdom, United Kingdom.

AN ZOOR14703025327
DT Article
TI First record of Syncarida from Queensland, Australia, with description
   of two new species of Notobathynella Schminke, 1973 (Crustacea,
   Bathynellacea, Parabathynellidae).
AU Camacho, A.I. (mcnac22@mncn.csic.es) 
   Hancock, P.
SO Journal of Natural History
VL 45
IS 1-2
PS 113-135
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB Two new species of the parabathynellid genus Notobathynella Schminke,
   1973 are described from Australia: N.octocamura sp. nov. and
   N.pentatrichion sp. nov. Notobathynella octocamura sp. nov. has eight
   claws on the distal endite of the maxillule, a character that is unique
   in the Parabathynellidae. It is also the first species of the genus with
   the following characters: five setae on the terminal segment of antenna,
   26-28 teeth on labrum, 31 setae on maxilla, a three-segmented exopod on
   thoracopod I, five-segmented exopods on thoracopods IV and V, three
   setae and two claws on the fourth endopodal segment of thoracopods I to
   IV, and six setae on the uropodal exopod. This species also has a unique
   setal formula for some thoracopods. Notobathynella pentatrichion sp.
   nov. is unique in the genus with five setae on the uropodal exopod and,
   like N.octocamura sp. nov., has a one- or two-segmented exopod on
   thoracopod I, a four- or five-segmented exopod of thoracopod V, and
   three setae and two claws in the four segments of the endopod of
   thoracopods II to IV. The two new species extend the distribution of
   Bathynellacea in Australia and are the first species to be described
   from Queensland.
C1 Camacho, A.I.; CSIC, Museo Nacl Ciencias Nat, C Jose Gutierrez Abascal
   2, Madrid, Spain, Spain.
EM mcnac22@mncn.csic.es
RI Camacho, Ana I/K-3565-2014
OI Camacho, Ana I/0000-0003-0596-7678
SC Zoology
SN 0022-2933
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Land zones;
   Australasian region; Australasia; Australia

   New species]. 
   Syncarida [Queensland /  / New record]. 
TN Arthropods; Crustaceans; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Crustacea, Malacostraca, Eumalacostraca,
   Syncarida, Bathynellacea
OR Syncarida (Eumalacostraca): [New record]. 
   Notobathynella - Schminke 1973 (Bathynellacea): [Diagnostic characters,
   P. 124; Included taxa, P. 134]. 
   Notobathynella octocamura (Bathynellacea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P. 114].
   
   Notobathynella pentatrichion (Bathynellacea): [Sp nov, Queensland, P.
   124]. 
DI 10.1080/00222933.2010.520824

PT J
AN ZOOR14703025334
DT Article
TI Ontogeny and phylogeny of Metaurostylopsis cheni sp n. (Protozoa,
   Ciliophora), with estimating the systematic position of
   Metaurostylopsis.
AU Chen, Xumiao (chenxumiao@163.com) 
   Huang, Jie
   Song, Weibo
SO Zoologica Scripta
VL 40
IS 1
PS 99-111
PD January 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 6
AB The ciliate genus Metaurostylopsis seems to be a highly divergent
   marine-habiting group, of which neither systematic position nor the
   variation of their ontogeny has been critically checked. In the present
   work, the morphology and morphogenesis during asexual division of a new
   form, Metaurostylopsis cheni sp. n., isolated from the Yellow Sea,
   China, were investigated and comparison among known congeners was
   performed. The new species has two types of cortical granules, the
   larger ones of which are flattened and oval or circular in outline with
   a longitudinal groove, yellow-green in colour, and arranged along the
   cirral rows and dorsal kineties, whereas the smaller ones are colourless
   or grayish and sparsely distributed. The main morphogenetic features
   are: (i) the entire parental ciliature, including the old oral
   apparatus, is renewed, (ii) the oral primordium of the proter originates
   de novo and beneath the surface of the buccal cavity, that is,
   sub-apokinetally, (iii) the anlagen of the marginal rows and of the
   dorsal kineties are formed intrakinetally and (iv) fusion of the
   macronuclear nodules results in an irregular mass with only few
   branches. The small subunit ribosomal RNA (SSU rRNA) gene of M. cheni
   was sequenced. Phylogenetic analysis based on SSU rRNA gene sequence
   data shows that M. cheni clusters with all other Metaurostylopsis spp.
   sequenced to date indicating that the genus is monophyletic and is
   probably closely related to the Apokeronopsis-Thigmokeronopsis-group,
   within the order Urostylida.
C1 Chen, Xumiao; Ocean Univ China, Inst Evolut & Marine Biodivers, Qingdao,
   China, China.
EM chenxumiao@163.com
RI Chen, Xumiao/D-5768-2019
SC Zoology; Developmental Biology; Genetics &Heredity; Evolutionary Biology
SN 0300-3256
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Taxonomy; Life cycle and
   development; Genetics; Evolution; Marine zones; Pacific Ocean
DE Metaurostylopsis [Development /  / taxonomic implications] [Molecular
   genetics / SSU rRNA gene sequence / ] [Phylogeny /  / ]. 
   Metaurostylopsis cheni [North Pacific / China, Shandong / New species]. 
TN Protozoans
ST Protozoa, Ciliophora, Polyhymenophorea, Spirotrichia, Hypotrichida
OR Metaurostylopsis - Song, Petz & Warren 2001 (Hypotrichida): [Diagnostic
   characters of subordinate taxa, P. 109; Taxonomic position, Placement in
   Urostylida, p. 109]. 
   Metaurostylopsis cheni (Hypotrichida): [Sp nov, China, Shandong
   (marine), P. 100]. 
DI 10.1111/j.1463-6409.2010.00451.x
UT ZOOREC:ZOOR14703025334
DA 2020-09-17
ER

PT J
AN ZOOR14805040045
DT Article
TI An additional contribution to the fauna of testate amoebae of the River
   Elbe Flood Discharge Canal near Magdeburg (Germany, Saxony-Anhalt) with
   first description of two new species: Allelogromia wanneri n. sp. und
   Clypeolina meisterfeldi n. sp.
FT Ein weiterer Beitrag zur Fauna der beschalten Amoeben im
   Elbe-Umflutkanal bei Magdeburg (Sachsen-Anhalt) mit Bieschreibung zwei
   neuer Arten: Allelogromia wanneri n. sp. und Clypeolina meisterfeldi n.
   sp.
AU Badewitz, Hans-Joachim
SO Abhandlungen und Berichte fuer Naturkunde
VL 33
PS 107-132
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA German
U1 0
U2 1
AB A second investigation of Testacean fauna takes place in the Elbe Flood
   Discharge Canal near the town of Magdeburg. 64 species of shelled
   amoebae have been found. The sampling area amounted to 3-5 m2. 11
   species are new proofs of the canal. To emphasize are records of
   Clypeolina marginata, Frenzelina minima and Hi'alosphenia punctata.
   Furthermore 2 new species have been described: Allelogromia wanneri n.
   sp. and Clypeolina meisterfeldi n. sp.

   Germany, Germany.

DT Article
TI FOUR NEW FEATHER MITE SPECIES OF THE FAMILY PTERONYSSIDAE (ASTIGMATA:
   ANALGOIDEA) FROM LAUGHING-THRUSHES (PASSERIFORMES: TIMALIIDAE) IN CHINA.
AU Mironov, S.V. (astigmata@zin.ru) 
   Proctor, H.C.
SO Acarina
VL 19
IS 1
PS 35-51
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Four new species of the feather mite family Pteronyssidae are described
   from passerines of the family Timaliidae in China (Guangxi and Guizhou
   Provinces): Mouchetia stachyris sp. n. from Stachyris ruficeps Blyth,
   Pteroherpus garrulacis sp. n. from Garrulax maesi (Oustalet),
   Timalinyssus curvilobus sp. n. from Garrulax sannio Swinhoe, and T
   grallator sp. n. from Alcippe chrysotis (Blyth). New data on
   distribution and host associations are provided for six more species of
   pteronyssids found in the area surveyed. Four species, M. indochinensis
   Mironov, 1990, P. pycnonoti Mironov, 1992, P krivolutskii Mironov, 1992
   and Pteronyssoides (Pteronyssoides) faini Mironov et Wauthy, 2005, are
   found in China for the first time; for the two latter species and for
   Pteronyssoides (Holonyssoides) desmiphorus (Gaud, 1952) and Timalinyssus
   longitarsus Wang et Wang, 2008 new avian hosts are recorded.
C1 Mironov, S.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Zool, Univ Skaya Quay 1, St
   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.

RI Proctor, Heather C./A-2677-2014

PT J

DT Article
TI MITES OF THE GENUS SCHIZOCARPUS (ACARIFORMES: CHIRODISCIDAE)
   PARASITIZING THE EURASIAN BEAVER CASTOR FIBER (RODENTIA: CASTORIDAE) IN
   THE VORONEZH NATURAL RESERVE.
AU Bochkov, A.V. (prostigmata@zin.ru) 
   Dubinina, H.V.
SO Acarina
VL 19
IS 1
PS 53-66
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 2
AB Fauna of fur mites of the genus Schizocarpus Trouessart, 1896
   (Acariformes: Chirodiscidae) associated with the Eurasian beaver Castor
   fiber L. (Rodentia: Castoridae) in the beaver farm of Voronezh National
   Reserve (Russia) was examined. Totally, 16 Schizocarpus spp. were
   recorded. Among them 11 species were previously described by Dubinina
   (1964) from the same locality and four following recovered species were
   formerly described by Fain and Lukoschus (1985) from Castor fiber in
   Western Europe: S. pygidialis, S. radiatus, S. similis, and S.
   subhexapilis. Available specimens of one more species close to S. latus
   (Dubinina, 1964) are determined as S. sp. and probably belong to a new
   species but are in the poor condition. Seven species described by
   Dubinina (1964) are redescribed: S. brevicauda, S. grandis, S. parvus,
   S. subparvus, S. minor, S. latus, and S. subminor. Two previously
   described species, S. dubininae Fain et Lukoschus, 1985 syn. nov. and S.
   ventricosus Fain et Lukoschus, 1985 syn. nov., are synonymized with S.
   grandis and S. latus, respectively. The record of S. mingaudi
   Trouessart, 1896 on Castor fiber from the Voronezh National Reserve by
   Dubinina (1964) is considered as the host shift from the American beaver
   Castor canadensis Kuhl happened in captivity at the Voronezh beaver
   farm.

   Petersburg, 199034, Russia, Russia.

   disorders; Parasites; Hosts; Land zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   [Russia / Voronezh Nature Reserve / ]. 
   Castor fiber orientoeuropaeus [Arachnid parasites / Schizocarpus
   pygidialis / ] [ / Schizocarpus radiatus / ] [ / Schizocarpus similis /
   ] [ / Schizocarpus subhexapilis / New record] [Russia / Voronezh Nature
   Reserve / ].

DT Article
TI ORIBATID MITES OF THE GENERA BASILOBELBA AND HETEROBELBA (ACARI:
   ORIBATIDA: AMEROIDEA) FROM BALE MOUNTAINS NATIONAL PARK (ETHIOPIA).
AU Ermilov, S.G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Sidorchuk, E.A.
   Rybalov, L.B.
SO Acarina
VL 19
IS 1
PS 67-75
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB We describe Basilobelba gigantea sp. n. and redescribe Heterobelba
   spumosa, collected in soil of Bale Mountains National Park (African
   region, Ethiopia). Basilobelba gigantea sp. n. is most similar in
   morphology prodorsal and epimeral setae, number of notogaster setae,
   morphology of arched scalp-attachment structures, weakly neotrichy on
   ventral plate to the Ghanaian species Basilobelba africana, but differs
   from it by body size, length of interlamellar setae and number of
   neotrichous. setae on the ventral plate. For the first time the data
   about morphology of gnathosoma, legs, and length of body setae are given
   for Heterobelba spumosa.
C1 Ermilov, S.G.; Fed Serv Vet & Phytosanit Inspect, Nizhniy Novgorod
   Referral Ctr, Nizhniy Novgorod, 603107, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0132-8077
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Description; Land zones;
   Afrotropical region; Africa

   Heterobelba spumosa [Ethiopia / Bale Mountains National Park /
   Systematics]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates

AB A new species, Parapygmephorus magnisetosus sp. n. (Acari:
   Neopygmephoridae), is described from the bees Halictus sexcinctus
   (Fabricius, 1775) and Osmia rufa (Linnaeus, 1758) (Hymenoptera:
   Halictidae and Megachilidae) from Ukraine. Parapygmephorus khorasanicus
   Hajiqanbar et Khaustov, 2011 is recorded for the first time for the
   Europe.

TI A NEW SPECIES OF EUSTIGMAEUS BERLESE (ACARI: PROSTIGMATA: STIGMAEIDAE)
   FROM NORTHWESTERN IRAN.
AU Irani-nejad, K. Haddad (Khaddad@tabrizu.ac.ir) 
   Lotfollahi, P.
   Akbari, A.
   Bagheri, M.
   Ueckermann, E.A.
SO Acarina
VL 19
IS 1
PS 87-90
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB A new species of Eustigmaeus Berlese (Acari: Prostigmata: Stigmaeidae),
   Eustigmaeus azerbaijanensis sp. n. is described and illustrated; The new
   species differs from the closely related species, Eustigmaeus coronaria
   Kuznetzov, 1977, in the shape of dorsal, ventral and coxal setae and
   number of paragenital setae. A key to the Iranian species of Eutigmaeus
   is provided.

DT Article
TI WATER MITES OF THE GENUS TIPHYS KOCH, 1836 (ACARIFORMES: PIONIDAE) IN
   RUSSIA.
AU Tuzovsky, P.V.
SO Acarina
VL 19
IS 2
PS 113-212
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 1
AB This study presents a detailed taxonomic review of water mites of the
   genus Tiphys Koch, 1836 (Hygrobatoidea: Pionidae) found in Russia during
   a long-term survey period between 1970 and 2008. The review includes
   (re)descriptions and illustrations of all known active stages of 18
   Tiphys species found in this country: Tiphys bullatus (Thor, 1899), T.
   ensifer (Koenike, 1895), T. uchidai Viets, 1956; T. lapponicus (Neuman,
   1880), T. latipes (Muller, 1776), T. pistillifer (Koenike, 1908), T.
   gladiator Tuzovskij, 2005; T. ornatus Koch, 1836; T. scaurus (Koenike,
   1892), T. scaurellus Tuzovskij, 1983; T. torris Koenike, 1914; T.
   anadyrensis sp. n., T. chaunensis sp. n., T. kamchatkaensis sp. n., T.
   kolymaensis sp. n., T minutiporus sp. n, T. samaraensis sp. n. and T.
   yaroslavlensis sp. n. Separate keys to all species based on females,
   males, deutonymphs and larvae are presented.
C1 Tuzovsky, P.V.; Russian Acad Sci, Inst Biol Inland Waters, Borok,
   Yaroslavl Province, 152742, Russia, Russia.
OI Tuzovsky, Petr/0000-0001-5002-2679
SC Zoology
SN 0132-8077

   zones; Palaearctic region; Eurasia

   Tiphys (Tiphys) anadyrensis; Tiphys (Tiphys) kamchatkaensis; Tiphys
   (Tiphys) kolymaensis; Tiphys (Tiphys) samaraensis; Tiphys (Tiphys)
   yaroslavlensis; Tiphys (Tiphys?) chaunensis; Tiphys (Tiphys?)
   minutiporus [Russia /  / New species].

PT J
AN ZOOR14803024141
DT Article
TI THE ORIBATID MITE FAMILIES NANHERMANNIIDAE AND LOHMANNIIDAE OF CAT TIEN
   NATIONAL PARK (VIETNAM).
AU Ermilov, S.G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Anichkin, A.E.
SO Acarina
VL 19
IS 2
PS 231-241
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 3
AB In the oribatid mite fauna of Cat Tien National Park (southern Vietnam),
   we discovered four species, each representating a different genus of the
   family Nanhermanniidae, and eight species representing four genera of
   Lohmanniidae. Our records of Cosmohermannia robusta and Masthermannia
   mammillaris (Nanhermanniidae) are the first for the respective genera
   from Vietnam; the lohmanniids Meristacarus sundensis, Mixacarus exilis,
   Papillacarus ramosus and P comutus are also newly reported from this
   country. The morphology of juvenile instars of Cosmohermannia robusta is
   described and illustrated. The juvenile instars of Cosmohermannia
   differs from those of Nanhermannia by the morphology of prodorsal and
   gastronotic setae, the presence two large latero-posterior body
   apophyses, the epimeral formulae, and the length of some epimeral setae.
   Diagnoses of juvenile instars of the family Nanhermanniidae and the
   genus Cosmohermannia are proposed. Papillacarus polygonatus sp. n. is
   described from dark loamy soil of a lagerstroemia forest; it differs
   from all other species of the genus by its larger body and three
   different forms of neotrichous setae.
C1 Ermilov, S.G.; Fed Serv Vet & Phytosanit Inspect, Nizhniy Novgorod
   Referral Ctr, Nizhniy Novgorod 603107, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru
SC Zoology
SN 0132-8077
BD Systematics; Nomenclature; New taxa; Diagnosis; Land zones; Oriental
   region; Eurasia; Asia
DE Cosmohermannia; Cosmohermannia robusta; Masthermannia; Masthermannia
   mammillaris; Meristacarus sundensis; Mixacarus exilis; Papillacarus
   cornutus; Papillacarus ramosus [Vietnam /  / New record]. 
   Lohmanniidae; Nanhermanniidae [Vietnam / Cat Tien National Park / Faunal
   list; new record; systematics]. 
   Papillacarus polygonatus [Vietnam /  / New species]. 
TN Arachnids; Arthropods; Chelicerates; Invertebrates
ST Animalia, Arthropoda, Arachnida, Acari
OR Cosmohermannia - Aoki & Yoshida 1970 (Acari): [Diagnostic characters,
   Juvenile instars, p. 236; New record]. 
   Cosmohermannia robusta (Acari): [Description, Juvenile instars, p. 232;
   New record]. 
   Lohmanniidae (Acari): [New record]. 
   Masthermannia (Acari): [New record]. 
   Masthermannia mammillaris (Acari): [New record]. 
   Meristacarus sundensis (Acari): [New record]. 
   Mixacarus exilis (Acari): [New record]. 
   Nanhermanniidae - Berlese 1913 (Acari): [Diagnostic characters, Juvenile
   instars, p. 236; New record]. 
   Papillacarus cornutus (Acari): [New record]. 
   Papillacarus polygonatus (Acari): [Sp nov, Vietnam, P. 236]. 
   Papillacarus ramosus (Acari): [New record].

PT J
AN ZOOR14803024142
DT Article
TI NEW ORIBATID MITES OF THE GENERA PERGALUMNA AND GALUMNELLA (ACARI,
   ORIBATIDA, GALUMNOIDEA) FROM VIETNAM.
AU Ermilov, S.G. (ermilovacari@yandex.ru) 
   Anichkin, A.E.
SO Acarina
VL 19
IS 2
PS 242-251
PD 2011
PY 2011
LA English
U1 0
U2 0
AB Three new species of oribatid mites of the superfamily Galumnoidea,
   Pergalumna cattienica sp. n., P. yurtaevi sp. n. and Galumnella
   microporosa sp. n., are described from Cat Tien National Park (southern
   Vietnam). Diagnostic keys to the Vietnamese species of Pergalumna and
   Asian of Galumnella are presented.

   Referral Ctr, Nizhniy Novgorod 603107, Russia, Russia.
EM ermilovacari@yandex.ru

   region; Palaearctic region; Eurasia; Asia

   [Vietnam /  / New species].
